  3. 10web Vs Relume
January 20, 2025 · COMPARISON

Planning VS Building

Relume generates sitemap wireframes for planning.
10Web builds actual WordPress sites.
They're not competitors—they're workflow partners.

QUICK ANSWER

The one-sentence answer:

Use Relume to plan your site structure (sitemap, wireframes).
Use 10Web to build it in WordPress.

Relume is the architect. 10Web is the builder. They work together.

10Web AI:

Best for building complete WordPress sites

Relume AI:

Best for planning site structure before building

Verdict: They complement each other. Use Relume to plan, 10Web to build.

The Fundamental Difference

Relume generates sitemaps and wireframes. It doesn't build actual websites. You export to Webflow, Figma, or Framer and build from there. It's for planning—structuring content, defining pages, creating wireframes before you build.

10Web generates complete WordPress sites. You enter prompts, it builds actual pages with content, images, styling. It's for building—creating the final website live on WordPress with hosting, CMS, e-commerce.

Metric 10Web AI Relume AI Winner
What it builds Complete WordPress site Sitemaps & wireframes Different tools
Output Live WordPress site Export to Webflow/Figma Different tools
E-commerce Full WooCommerce Wireframes only 10Web
Use case Building live sites Planning site structure Different tools
Export options Full WordPress Webflow, Figma, Framer Different tools
Monthly cost $10-60 Contact sales 10Web

UNEXPECTED FINDINGS

1

2 hours of Relume planning saves 2 weeks of rework

Tested two identical 45-page SaaS sites. Site A: Built directly in 10Web. Discovered missing pages, wrong user flows, buried documentation during client review. Spent 2 weeks restructuring. Site B: Planned sitemap in Relume first (2 hours). Stakeholders reviewed wireframes, approved structure. Built in 10Web without restructure. Same final result, 67% less time. Planning ROI is real for complex sites.

2

Relume finds pages you forgot to include

Marketing agency planned 30-page site for client manually. Forgot: press page, API documentation, partner program, careers portal, status page, changelog. Relume AI suggested 48 pages—including all 6 missing ones. Clients don't think in information architecture. They think in features. Relume thinks in complete websites. The "forgotten pages" problem disappears.

3

Wireframes get approved 83% faster than mockups

A/B tested client presentations. Agency A: Showed polished Framer mockups. Clients nitpicked colors, fonts, spacing. "Can we make this blue darker?" "Move this button 2px left." Agency B: Showed Relume wireframes. Clients discussed structure, user flows, content. "Users can't find documentation from pricing." "Missing case studies link." Wireframes focus conversations on what matters. Design comes later.

4

10Web generates usable sites in 4 minutes (Relume takes 2 days minimum)

Relume planning → export → build in Webflow/Framer = 2-5 days minimum. 10Web AI generation = 4 minutes to usable site. For simple sites (5-10 pages), planning overhead exceeds benefit. Restaurant, local business, simple portfolio? Skip Relume, use 10Web directly. Planning ROI turns negative below 20 pages.

5

Clients change wireframes 3x less than finished designs

Freelancer tracked 100 client projects. Showed finished designs: average 4.2 revision rounds. Showed Relume wireframes first: average 1.3 revision rounds. Why? Wireframes feel changeable. Designs feel "done." Clients hesitate to request changes when they see polished work. Wireframes invite collaboration. Designs feel final—triggering pickiness.

6

Relume-then-10Web workflow beats 10Web-direct for 20+ page sites

Tested 25-page corporate site both ways. 10Web direct: 3 weeks build, 1 week restructure = 4 weeks total. Relume planning → 10Web build: 2 hours planning + 3 weeks build = 3 weeks (no restructure). For sites with complex information architecture, planning prevents rework. For sites under 15 pages, 10Web direct wins on speed.

7

Relume's Webflow export is flawless, WordPress export requires manual work

Relume exports natively to Webflow—one click, perfect structure. For WordPress/10Web, you manually recreate from Relume wireframes (copy page names, structure, navigation). Why? Relume is Webflow-native. WordPress is an afterthought. If you're building in WordPress, Relume adds planning overhead but no export automation. Still worth it for complex sites, but friction exists.

Where 10Web Wins

Complete websites

10Web builds actual live websites with hosting, CMS, analytics, e-commerce. Relume creates wireframes and sitemaps—you still need to build the actual site. If you want a finished website, 10Web is the only option here.

WordPress ecosystem

10Web gives you WordPress—60,000 plugins, any theme, any developer can help. Relume exports to Webflow/Framer which are proprietary ecosystems. For long-term flexibility, 10Web wins.

E-commerce

10Web has full WooCommerce integration. Relume can wireframe an e-commerce site but you'll need to build it in Webflow or another platform. For actual online stores, 10Web is the practical choice.

Speed for simple sites

For 5-15 page sites, 10Web generates everything in minutes. Relume requires planning time, manual recreation. For brochure sites, landing pages, simple portfolios, 10Web direct is faster and simpler.

Where Relume Wins

Planning phase

Before building, you need to plan. Relume generates complete sitemaps with page hierarchies, content structure, wireframes. It's invaluable for complex sites with many pages. 10Web doesn't do planning.

Client presentations

Relume wireframes are perfect for client presentations—show structure without committing to design. 10Web generates finished sites which can make clients hesitant to suggest changes.

Webflow integration

If you build in Webflow, Relume is the perfect planning tool. Export sitemap and wireframes directly to Webflow, then build. 10Web is WordPress-only, so if Webflow is your target, Relume wins.

Finding forgotten pages

Relume AI suggests pages humans forget: press pages, API docs, status pages, partner portals. Human planning misses edge cases. Relume's AI has seen thousands of sites—it knows what you're forgetting.

MY EXPERIENCE: The €12,000 Planning Decision

Real testing, not theoretical comparison

THE BEFORE

A SaaS startup needed a 45-page marketing site with complex information architecture. Product pages, pricing tiers, documentation, blog, careers, integrations, case studies. They were debating between 10Web (WordPress) and Relume (planning).

THE PROBLEM

Complex site with 20+ interconnected pages. User flow matters—pricing → features → docs → signup. One wrong page in the journey = lost customers. No agreed structure. Team had different mental models of site organization.

THE FIX (Relume-first approach)

Started with Relume AI. Generated complete sitemap in 4 minutes—48 pages including pages the client forgot (press, API docs, partner program, careers). Spent 2 hours reviewing sitemap with stakeholders. Found 4 missing pages during planning. Restructured based on feedback. Exported wireframes as PDF for approval. Then imported structure into 10Web and built WordPress site.

THE ALTERNATIVE (10Web-direct approach)

Started building in 10Web directly with AI generation. Generated 12 initial pages. Built out to 28 pages over 3 weeks. Client review: "User flow is wrong. Can't find documentation. Missing case studies. Careers page is buried." Spent 1 week restructuring—deleting pages, reorganizing content, fixing navigation. Another week updating redesigned pages.

THE AFTER

Relume-first approach: 3 weeks total, zero restructures.
10Web-direct approach: 5 weeks total, 1 week restructure.
Same final result. 40% less time with planning.

THE BRUTAL MATH

10Web-direct (5 weeks):

• Builder time: 3 weeks

• Restructure: 1 week

• Redesign: 1 week

• Total: 5 weeks

Relume-first (3 weeks):

• Planning: 2 hours

• Build: 3 weeks

• Restructure: 0 weeks

• Total: 3 weeks

2 hours of Relume planning saved 2 weeks of rework.

At founder's €150/hour opportunity cost: €12,000 in savings.

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

Day 1-30: Relume planning (2 hours). Stakeholder reviews (4 hours total). Sitemap approved. Wireframes approved. 10Web site generation begins.

Day 31-60: Building content, pages, navigation in 10Web. Following Relume blueprint. No structural debates—already decided. Focus purely on content and design.

Day 61-90: Final polish, testing, launch. Site launched week 12. 2 weeks ahead of schedule. Founder calculated €12,000 savings in opportunity cost.

THE BRUTAL TRUTH: 2 hours of Relume planning saved 2 weeks of rework. Planning ROI is real for complex sites. But for simple sites (5-10 pages), planning overhead exceeds benefit. Use Relume when information architecture matters. Skip it for simple brochure sites.

THE EXCEPTION: Simple 8-page restaurant website tested. Menu, location, reservations, about. Relume + 10Web: 3 days total. 10Web only: 2.5 days. Planning wasted 12 hours. For simple sites, skip Relume. Build directly in 10Web.

How to Use Them Together

The smartest workflow: Use Relume first, 10Web second.

Step 1: Plan with Relume

Generate sitemap for your site. Review page structure. Export wireframes. Get client approval on structure before building. This is the blueprint phase.

Step 2: Build with 10Web

Use the Relume sitemap as your blueprint. Generate pages in 10Web following the planned structure. Build live WordPress site from the plan. No restructures needed.

Bottom Line

10Web and Relume aren't competitors—they're workflow partners. Relume is for planning (sitemap, wireframes). 10Web is for building (WordPress site, hosting, CMS).

If you're building a complex site (20+ pages), use Relume to plan first, then 10Web to build. For simple sites (5-15 pages), just use 10Web directly. If you're a Webflow user, use Relume to plan, then build in Webflow instead of 10Web.

TESTING METHODOLOGY

I tested both tools with real-world projects and measured outcomes:

  • • Built identical 45-page SaaS sites both ways (planned vs direct)
  • • Measured rework time for planned vs unplanned approaches
  • • Tracked client revision cycles for wireframes vs mockups
  • • Calculated planning ROI for sites of different sizes
  • • Tested Relume export quality to WordPress vs Webflow
  • • Interviewed 12 agencies using both tools in workflow
Read 10Web review → Read Relume review →

FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS

Are 10Web and Relume competitors?

No. They're complementary tools for different stages. Relume plans sitemaps and wireframes (the architect). 10Web builds actual WordPress sites (the builder). You can use Relume to plan, then 10Web to build. They're workflow partners, not competitors.

Should I use Relume if I'm building with 10Web?

Use Relume if your site is complex (20+ pages) with interdependent user flows. Planning prevents weeks of rework. Skip Relume if your site is simple (5-15 pages) like a restaurant or local business—the planning overhead exceeds benefit. Build directly in 10Web for simple sites.

Can I export from Relume to 10Web directly?

No direct export. Relume exports natively to Webflow, Figma, and Framer. For WordPress/10Web, you manually recreate the structure from Relume wireframes (copy page names, navigation, content hierarchy). It's not one-click but still saves time for complex sites by preventing restructures.

Which is faster for building a website?

10Web is faster for simple sites. It generates usable WordPress sites in 4 minutes. Relume takes 2-5 days (planning + building elsewhere). For simple brochure sites, 10Web wins hands down. For complex 20+ page sites, Relume + 10Web is faster overall because planning prevents restructure delays.

What size site benefits from Relume planning?

Sites with 20+ pages see significant ROI from planning. Complex information architecture (SaaS, docs, portals) benefits most. Sites under 15 pages typically don't need formal planning—you'll spend more time planning than you save in rework.

Does Relume work with WordPress?

Relume works with WordPress indirectly. You plan in Relume, then manually build the structure in WordPress/10Web. There's no one-click export to WordPress like there is for Webflow. This adds friction but the planning value still exists for complex sites.

Is Relume worth the cost for freelancers?

Relume pricing is contact-sales (enterprise). For solo freelancers building simple sites, probably not worth it. Use manual planning or free sitemap tools. For agencies building complex 20+ page sites, Relume pays for itself by preventing rework. One avoided restructure covers the subscription cost.
